case_data.summary: In June 2006, the EEOC district office in Phoenix, Arizona brought this suit against RV Fun, Inc., doing business as Cowboys RV Mart, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona. The EEOC claimed that the defendant violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) when it refused to accommodate an employee with ADD, then terminated him for asking for an accommodation.  The parties settled and a consent decree was entered in December 2006. The defendant agreed to pay the aggrieved party $30,000, refrain from retaliating and discriminating based on disability, implement an ADA/anti-discrimination policy, distribute and post its policy, post an EEO notice, provide EEO training to all its employees and CEO, hire an EEO consultant, implement a complaint procedure, make no references to this litigation in the aggrieved party's personnel file, issue an apology letter, and submit semiannual compliance/complaint reports to the EEOC. The docket sheet shows that no further enforcement took place; the case was presumably closed in 2008.

ATTACHMENT A 
NOTICE TO ALL EMPLOYEES OF 
RV FUN, INC (doing business as COWBOY’S RV MART) 
This notice is posted pursuant to a consent decree entered into in the Americans 
EEOC v. RV Fun, Inc., d/b/a Cowboy’s RV Mart
with Disabilities Act case  , CIV-
06-1675-PCT-EHC.
It is unlawful under federal law (the Americans with Disabilities Act) and state law 
to discriminate against an employee on the basis of disability.  It is also unlawful to 
retaliate against any person because the person protested discriminatory practices 
or contacted the EEOC. 
Cowboy’s RV Mart will not discriminate against any employee on the basis of 
disability and will not retaliate against any employee. 
If you believe you have been discriminated against by Cowboy’s RV Mart, you 
have the right to seek assistance from: 
  (1)  EEOC, 3300 North Central Avenue, Suite 690, Phoenix, Arizona 
85012, (602) 640-5000; or 
  (2)  Arizona Civil Rights Division (ACRD) of the Attorney General's 
Office, 1275 W. Washington, Phoenix, Arizona, 85007, (602) 255-5263. 
and/or have the right to file a charge with the EEOC or ACRD if you believe you 
are being discriminated against. 
No Retaliation Clause.  No action may be taken against you by any supervisory or 
management official of Cowboy’s RV Mart  for (1) opposing discriminatory 
practices made unlawful by federal law, (2) filing a charge or assisting or 
participating in the filing of a charge of discrimination, or (3) assisting or 
participating in an investigation or proceeding brought under state or federal law 
anti-discrimination laws.  Should any such retaliatory actions be taken against you, 
you should immediately contact the EEOC or the ACRD and the address or 
telephone numbers listed above.

      Sherman Henson 
RV Fun, Inc./Cowboy’s RV Mart

As you are aware, a lawsuit was filed by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission 
against RV Fun, Inc. (doing business as Cowboy’s RV Mart) alleging termination based on 
disability and failure to reasonably accommodate you. 
Please accept my apology on behalf of myself and Cowboy’s RV Mart for any failure to 
accommodate you and negative treatment you endured because of your disability while you 
worked for us.  Please accept my commitment that the company will take the necessary steps to 
ensure that current and future employees with disabilities will be accommodated and that 
employees will not be subjected to any harassment or retaliation.  
I appreciate the service you provided to us.  I wish you the best of luck in the future. 
Sincerely,
Sherman Henson 
CEO, RV Fun, Inc. (doing business as Cowboy’s RV Mart)

19 NATURE OF THE ACTION
20 This is an action under Titles I and V of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 
21 (“ADA”) and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 to correct unlawful employment 
practices on the basis of disability and to provide appropriate relief to Christiaan C. 
22
Calhoon, who was adversely affected by such practices.   The Commission alleges that 
23
RV Fun, Inc. (“RV Fun”) discriminated against Mr. Calhoon on the basis of his 
24
25 disability, Attention Deficit Disorder (“ADD”), when it denied him a reasonable 
26 accommodation in his position of Recreational Vehicle (RV) Cleaner and Washer and 
27 when it discharged him because of his disability and because he requested a reasonable 
accommodation.
28

employment practices at its Lake Havasu City, Arizona location, in violation of Titles I 
11
and V of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq. These practices include: 
12
a.   Denying Mr. Calhoon a reasonable accommodation; 
13
  b.  Discharging Mr. Calhoon because of his disability; and 
14
  c.  Discharging Mr. Calhoon because he requested a reasonable 
15
accommodation.
16
11.  The effect of the practices complained of in paragraph 10 above has been to 
17
deprive Christiaan Calhoon of equal employment opportunities and otherwise adversely 
18
affect his status as an employee because of his disability.
19
12.  The unlawful employment practices complained of in paragraph 10 were 
20
intentional.
21
13.  The unlawful employment practices complained of in paragraph 10 above were 
22
done with malice or with reckless indifference to the federally protected rights of 
23
Christiaan Calhoon.
24
25
26
27
28
-3-

PRAYER FOR RELIEF
1
  Wherefore, the Commission respectfully requests that this Court: 
2
A.  Grant a permanent injunction enjoining Defendant RV Fun, its officers, 
3
successors, assigns, and all persons in active concert or participation with it, from 
4
engaging in those actions alleged in paragraph 10 and any other employment practice 
5
which discriminates on the basis of disability. 
6
B.  Order Defendant RV Fun to institute and carry out policies, practices, and 
7
programs which provide equal employment opportunities for qualified individuals with 
8
disability, and which eradicate the effects of its past and present unlawful employment 
9
practices.
10
C.  Order Defendant RV Fun to make whole Christiaan Calhoon by providing 
11
appropriate back pay with prejudgment interest, in amounts to be determined at trial, and 
12
other affirmative relief necessary to eradicate the effects of its unlawful employment 
13
practices, including but not limited to institution of training programs which educate 
14
employees about disability and anti-discrimination laws and transmission of a letter of 
15
apology to Christiaan Calhoon.  
16
D.  Order Defendant RV Fun to make whole Christiaan Calhoon by providing 
17
compensation for past and future nonpecuniary losses resulting from the unlawful 
18
practices complained of in paragraph 10 above, including emotional pain, suffering, 
19
inconvenience, loss of enjoyment of life, and humiliation, in amounts to be determined at 
20
trial.
21
E.  Order Defendant RV Fun to pay Christiaan Calhoon punitive damages for its 
22
malicious and reckless conduct, as described in paragraph 10 above, in amounts to be 
23
determined at trial. 
24
F.  Grant such further relief as the Court deems necessary and proper in the public 
25
interest.
26
G.  Award the Commission its costs in this action. 
27
28
-4-

  The Commission requests a jury trial on all questions of fact raised by its 
2
complaint.
3
4

18 NATURE OF THE ACTION
19 This is an action under Titles I and V of the Americans with Disabilities Act of
20
1990 ("ADA") and Title I of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 to correct unlawful employment
21
practices on the basis of disability and to provide appropriate relief to Christiaan C.
22
Calhoon, who was adversely affected by such practices.   The Commission alleges that
23
RV Fun, Inc. ("RV Fun") discriminated against Mr. Calhoon on the basis of his disability,
24
Attention Deficit Disorder ("ADD"), when it denied him a reasonable accommodation in
25
his position of Recreational Vehicle (RV) Cleaner and Washer and when it discharged
26
27 him because of his disability and because he requested a reasonable accommodation. 
28

1 JURISDICTION AND VENUE
2 1. Jurisdiction of this Court is invoked pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 451, 1331, 1337,
3 1343 and 1345.  This action is authorized and instituted pursuant to Section 107(a) of the
4 Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA"), 42 U.S.C. § 12117(a), which
5 incorporates by reference Sections 706(f)(1) and (3) of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act
6 of 1964 ("Title VII"), 42 U.S.C. §§ 2000e-5(f)(1) and (3), and pursuant to Section 102 of
7 the Civil Rights Act of 1991, 42 U.S.C. § 1981a.
8 2. The employment practices alleged to be unlawful were committed within the
9 jurisdiction of the United States District Court for the District of Arizona.
10 PARTIES
11 3. Plaintiff, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (the "Commission"), is
12 the agency of the United States of America charged with the administration, interpretation
13 and enforcement of Title I of the ADA and is expressly authorized to bring this action by
14 Section 107(a) of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12117(a), which incorporates by reference
15 Sections 706(f)(1) and (3)  of Title VII, 42 U.S.C.  §§ 2000e-5(f)(1).
16 4. At all relevant times, Defendant, RV Fun, Inc., an Arizona corporation, has
17 continuously been doing business in the state of Arizona and the city of Lake Havasu
18 City, and has continuously had at least 15 employees.
19 5. At all relevant times, Defendant has continuously been an employer engaged in an
20 industry affecting commerce under Section 101(5) of the ADA, 42 U.S.C.§ 12111(5), and
21 Section 101(7) of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12111(7), which incorporates by reference
22 Sections 701(g) and (h) of Title VII, 42 U.S.C. §§ 2000e(g) and (h).
23 6. At all relevant times, Defendant has been a covered entity under Section 101(2) of
24 the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12111(2).
25 . . .
26 . . .
27 . . .
28 . . .
2

1 STATEMENT OF CLAIMS
2 7. More than thirty days prior to the institution of this lawsuit, Christiaan Calhoon
3 filed a charge with the Commission alleging violations of Titles I and V of the ADA by
4 Defendant RV Fun.  All conditions precedent to the institution of this lawsuit have been
5 fulfilled.
6 8. Christiaan Calhoon is a qualified individual with a disability and is covered by
7 Title I of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq.
8 9. Christiaan Calhoon is experienced in commercial janitorial and cleaning work and
9 worked in a janitorial and cleaning capacity for RV Fun.
10 10. Since at least April 7, 2004, Defendant RV Fun has engaged in unlawful
11 employment practices at its Lake Havasu City, Arizona location, in violation of Titles I
12 and V of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq.  These practices include:
13 a.  Denying Mr. Calhoon a reasonable accommodation;
14 b. Discharging Mr. Calhoon because of his disability;
15 c. Discharging Mr. Calhoon because he requested a reasonable
16 accommodation.
17 11. The effect of the practices complained of in paragraph 10 above has been to
18 deprive Christiaan Calhoon of equal employment opportunities and otherwise adversely
19 affect his status as an employee because of his disability.  
20 12. The unlawful employment practices complained of in paragraph 10 were
21 intentional.
22 13. The unlawful employment practices complained of in paragraph 10 above were
23 done with malice or with reckless indifference to the federally protected rights of
24 Christiaan Calhoon. 
25  . . .
26  . . .
27  . . .
28  . . .
3

1 PRAYER FOR RELIEF
2 Wherefore, the Commission respectfully requests that this Court:
3 A. Grant a permanent injunction enjoining Defendant RV Fun, its officers,
4 successors, assigns, and all persons in active concert or participation with it, from
5 engaging in those actions alleged in paragraph 10 and any other employment practice
6 which discriminates on the basis of disability.
7 B. Order Defendant RV Fun to institute and carry out policies, practices, and
8 programs which provide equal employment opportunities for qualified individuals with
9 disability, and which eradicate the effects of its past and present unlawful employment
10 practices.
11 C. Order Defendant RV Fun to make whole Christiaan Calhoon by providing
12 appropriate back pay with prejudgment interest, in amounts to be determined at trial, and
13 other affirmative relief necessary to eradicate the effects of its unlawful employment
14 practices, including but not limited to institution of training programs which educate
15 employees about disability and anti-discrimination laws and transmission of a letter of
16 apology to Christiaan Calhoon. 
17 D. Order Defendant RV Fun to make whole Christiaan Calhoon by providing
18 compensation for past and future nonpecuniary losses resulting from the unlawful
19 practices complained of in paragraph 10 above, including emotional pain, suffering,
20 inconvenience, loss of enjoyment of life, and humiliation, in amounts to be determined at
21 trial.
22 E. Order Defendant RV Fun to pay Christiaan Calhoon punitive damages for its
23 malicious and reckless conduct, as described in paragraph 10 above, in amounts to be
24 determined at trial.
25 F. Grant such further relief as the Court deems necessary and proper in the public
26 interest.
27 G. Award the Commission its costs in this action.
28
4

2 The Commission requests a jury trial on all questions of fact raised by its
3 complaint.

documents.text:
1
2
3
4

8
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
9
FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
10
11 EQUAL EMPLOYMENT  )
)   CV06-1675-PCT-EHC 
OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION, 
12 )
) CONSENT DECREE 
13              Plaintiff,  )
)
  vs. 
14 )
)
15 RV FUN, INC., an Arizona corporation,  )
)
d/b/a COWBOYS RV MART, 
16 )
)
17              Defendant.  )
)
18
19
The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (the 
20
"Commission") filed this action against RV Fun, Inc., doing business as Cowboy’s RV 
21
Mart, under Title I of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) of 1990 and Title I of 
22
the Civil Rights Act of 1991 to correct unlawful employment practices on the basis of 
23
disability and to provide appropriate relief to Christiaan Calhoon, who was adversely 
24
affected by such practices.  The Commission alleged that RV Fun, Inc. discriminated 
25
against Mr. Calhoon on the basis of his disability, Attention Deficit Disorder (“ADD”), 
26
by denying him a reasonable accommodation in his position of Recreational Vehicle 
27
28
-1-

(RV) Cleaner and Washer and by discharging him because of his disability and because 
1
he requested a reasonable accommodation. 
2
The Parties do not object to the jurisdiction of the Court over this action and waive 
3
their rights to a hearing and the entry of findings of fact and conclusions of law.  The 
4
parties agree that this Consent Decree is fair, reasonable, and equitable and does not 
5
violate the law or public policy. 
6
In the interest of resolving this matter, and as a result of having engaged in 
7
comprehensive settlement negotiations, the Parties agree that this action should be finally 
8
resolved by entry of this Decree. 
9
It is ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED: 
10
1.  This Decree resolves all claims arising out of the issues between the 
11
Commission and Defendant RV Fun, Inc. (“RV Fun” or “Defendant”) in this lawsuit or 
12
raised in the charge of Christiaan Calhoon, No. 350-2004-03346, including without 
13
limitation, back pay, compensatory and punitive damages, injunctive relief, costs and 
14
attorney's fees. 
15
INJUNCTION 
16
2.  Defendant and its officers, agents, employees, successors, and assigns both 
17
at the time that this Decree becomes effective and for the duration of this Decree, are 
18
enjoined from: (a) discriminating against any employee on the basis of disability; (b) 
19
altering the terms and conditions of any employee’s employment because of disability; 
20
(c) refusing to reasonably accommodate any employee who requires a reasonable 
21
accommodation, as required by the ADA, and; (d) retaliating against any employee 
22
because he or she: (i) opposes or opposed discriminatory practices made unlawful by 
23
ADA; (ii) files or filed a charge of discrimination or assists, assisted, participates, or 
24
participated in the filing of a charge of discrimination; or (iii) assists, assisted, 
25
participates or participated in an investigation or proceeding brought under the Federal or 
26
State laws prohibiting discrimination or retaliation. 
27
28
-2-

MONETARY RELIEF 
1
3.  Defendant shall pay the amount of $30,000.  The payment shall be made 
2
directly to Christiaan Calhoon by check or money order at the address provided by the 
3
EEOC.  This payment represents settlement of compensatory damages.  Defendant shall 
4
make no deductions from this amount.  The compensation is to be paid within ten (10) 
5
calendar days of the entry of this Consent Decree.  By January 31, 2007, Defendant shall 
6
issue United States Internal Revenue Service Form 1099 to Mr. Calhoon for the payment. 
7
4.  Within 5 business days of the date the check or money order is placed in 
8
the mail pursuant to this Consent Decree, a copy of the check will be furnished to the 
9
Regional Attorney, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Phoenix District 
10
Office, 3300 North Central Avenue, Suite 690, Phoenix, Arizona 85012.  
11
OTHER RELIEF 
12
5.  Defendant will institute and carry out policies and procedures that help 
13
assure a work environment free from disability discrimination for its employees, that 
14
allow employees to raise concerns or complaints without retaliation about matters, 
15
whether alleged, perceived or actual, made unlawful by the ADA and that provide 
16
procedures for employees to request reasonable accommodations. 
17
6.  Defendant will post the Notice contained in the attached Attachment A.
18
The Notice will be posted in an appropriate place frequented by employees, for the 
19
duration of this decree.  The Notice shall be the same type, size, and style as Attachment 
20
A.
21
7.  To assist Defendant in understanding disability discrimination, Defendant 
22
shall require its CEO, Sherman Henson, to attend a course, seminar or training session on 
23
awareness of and sensitivity to disabilities, which includes mental disabilities.
24
a.  Defendant will arrange for and be financially responsible for the 
25
course, seminar, or training session. 
26
b.  The course, seminar, or training session selected shall be subject to 
27
approval by the Commission. 
28
-3-

c.  The training shall be at least two (2) hours in length, including 
1
twenty (20) minutes for questions and answers.   
2
d.  The training shall be completed within ninety (90) days of entry of 
3
this consent decree. 
4
e.  The training shall focus on the ADA, including mental disabilities.
5
The Training will include the subject of what constitutes a disability and shall also 
6
cover typical manifestations of mental disabilities in the workplace at both the 
7
application and employment phases; common challenges faced by individuals with 
8
mental disabilities in the workplace; the interactive process and possible 
9
accommodations of mental disabilities; and informational resources available to 
10
employers of individuals with mental disabilities. 
11
8.  To assist Defendant in achieving and maintaining compliance in the area of 
12
anti-discrimination and equal employment opportunity with respect to the ADA, within 
13
sixty (60) days of the entry of the Decree, Defendant will select, subject to approval of 
14
the EEOC, an appropriate and qualified employee or appropriate and qualified third-party 
15
administrator to be responsible for the duties described in Paragraph 9.   The EEOC shall 
16
notify Defendant within fourteen (14) days whether or not it approves of Defendant’s 
17
choice.  If Defendant selects one of its employees rather than a third-party administrator, 
18
the EEOC may condition its approval of the selectee upon the selectee’s completion of 
19
additional training on disability discrimination and the provisions of the ADA.    The 
20
training in paragraph 7 shall suffice.  In the event that the EEOC and Defendant are 
21
unable to agree on the selection of an employee or third-party administrator, they may 
22
each submit the names and curriculum vitae of not more than two proposed employees or 
23
third-party administrators, and the Court will make the selection. 
24
9.  The employee or third-party administrator selected pursuant to Paragraph 8 
25
shall be responsible for:  (a) creating and implementing, and/or reviewing and revising, 
26
Defendant's ADA anti-discrimination policies; (b) creating and implementing, and/or 
27
reviewing and revising, Defendant’s procedures with respect to responding to and 
28
-4-

keeping records regarding ADA complaints received; (c) receiving and investigating 
1
ADA complaints of discrimination; (d) evaluating and, if appropriate, referring 
2
employees to Defendant for discipline or termination for violation of Defendant's anti-
3
discrimination policies; (e) evaluating employees in the area of anti-discrimination/equal 
4
employment opportunity policies with respect to the ADA; and (f) preparing reports to 
5
the Commission, as required by this Decree.
6
10.  Defendant will provide training on disability discrimination and retaliation, 
7
according to the following terms:
8
a.  Defendant will arrange for and be financially responsible for a 
9
consultant/lecturer(s) who will provide consultation and a training session for all 
10
of its employees.  The training session(s) shall be provided jointly by the 
11
consultant/lecturer(s). 
12
b.  The seminar training session shall be at least one and one-half (1 ½) 
13
hours in length, including thirty (30) minutes for questions and answers.  All of 
14
Defendant’s supervisory, management and non-supervisory employees shall attend 
15
the seminar session.   
16
c.  Defendant shall keep a written record of all employees who attend 
17
the training.  Defendant may at its election have duplicative sessions to 
18
accommodate staffing needs or videotape the training session.  Defendant shall be 
19
responsible for any additional costs to provide such duplicative or videotaped 
20
sessions.
21
d.  The seminar-training session shall be held within four months of the 
22
entry of the consent decree. 
23
e.  All personnel, designated in Paragraphs 10(a) and (b) above, shall 
24
both register for and attend the seminar-training session or view a videotape of the 
25
session.  The registry of attendance shall be retained by Defendant for the duration 
26
of the Decree.
27
28
-5-

f.  The training will include the subject of what constitutes disability 
1
discrimination, as well as retaliation for engaging in protected activity under the 
2
ADA.  In addition, the training will cover the myths often associated with the 
3
ability of disabled individuals to work. The training will also cover discrimination 
4
in violation of the ADA in the hiring, firing, compensation, assignment or other 
5
terms, conditions or privileges of employment; the prevention of discrimination; 
6
how to provide a work environment free from discrimination, harassment and 
7
retaliation; and to whom and by what means employees may complain if they feel 
8
they have been subjected to discrimination, harassment or retaliation in the 
9
workplace. The session shall also review and explain Defendant's disability 
10
policies.
11
11.  During the live training session(s), Defendant’s CEO will speak to the 
12
employees about the discipline that can be taken against supervisors, managers and 
13
employees who commit acts of disability discrimination, harassment or retaliation or 
14
allow discrimination, harassment or retaliation to occur in the workplace; the importance 
15
of maintaining an environment free of discrimination; and Defendant's ADA anti-
16
discrimination policies.  
17
12.  The Commission, at its discretion, may designate representatives to attend 
18
the seminar-training sessions. The representatives shall have the right to participate in the 
19
sessions.
20
13.  Within ninety (90) days of the entry of this Decree, Defendant will create 
21
and implement written policies concerning discrimination and retaliation that conform 
22
with the law.  Defendant’s written policies must include, at a minimum:
23
a.  A strong and clear commitment to a workplace free of disability 
24
discrimination;  
25
b.  A clear and strong encouragement of persons who believe they have 
26
been discriminated against to come forward;  
27
28
-6-

c.  A description of the consequences, up to and including termination, 
1
that will be imposed upon violators of the policy;
2
d.  A statement of Defendant’s intent to handle complaints of disability 
3
discrimination as confidentially as appropriate under the circumstances;   
4
e.  An assurance of non-retaliation for persons who believe they have 
5
been discriminated against and for witnesses of discrimination;  
6
f.  That discrimination on the basis of disability by anyone, including 
7
management officials, supervisors, vendors, suppliers, third parties and customers, 
8
is prohibited and will not be tolerated; 
9
g.  The identification of specific alternative individuals, including 
10
managers with their telephone numbers, to whom employees who have been 
11
subjected to disability discrimination can report the discrimination and who have 
12
the authority to investigate allegations of discrimination in a neutral and 
13
confidential manner; 
14
h.  A written statement that an employee may report the harassment to a 
15
designated person outside of his or her chain of management should the 
16
complainant believe managers in the chain of command have a conflict of interest, 
17
are implicated in the allegations, or may not adequately investigate the complaint;
18
i.  Assurances that Defendant will investigate allegations of disability 
19
discrimination promptly, fairly, reasonably and effectively by appropriate 
20
investigators and that appropriate corrective action will be taken by Defendant to 
21
make victims whole and to eradicate the discrimination; 
22
j.  A written statement assuring employees who need a reasonable 
23
accommodation to enable them to complain or to participate in the investigation 
24
process that they shall be provided such accommodation and advising them how to 
25
obtain such accommodation.  The statement shall also include a provision stating 
26
that managers are not allowed to withdraw previously approved accommodations 
27
without approval of the CEO; and 
28
-7-

k.  Information regarding the employee's right to file a charge of 
1
discrimination with the EEOC or the Arizona Civil Rights Division (“ACRD”), 
2
including contact telephone, TDY/TDD and addresses for the EEOC and ACRD. 
3
14.  These policies shall be posted in a prominent location at Defendant’s 
4
facilities in Arizona.  These policies shall be transmitted to Defendant’s employees by its 
5
CEO and distributed to each current employee within ninety (90) days of the entry of the 
6
Decree. These policies shall be distributed to all new employees when hired.  These 
7
policies also shall be posted in a prominent place frequented by Defendant’s employees. 
8
Defendant shall make these written policies available in alternative formats as necessary 
9
for persons with cognitive and print disabilities that may prevent them from reading the 
10
policies. Alternative formats will include but not be limited to an audiotape format. 
11
15.  Defendant shall promptly and appropriately investigate all complaints of 
12
disability discrimination.  The investigation must include a finding of whether 
13
discrimination occurred, a credibility assessment; interviews of all potential victims and 
14
witnesses identified; and concurrent notes of the investigation. Defendant shall take 
15
immediate appropriate corrective action to make discrimination victims whole, to 
16
discipline violators and to eradicate the discrimination.
17
16.  Defendant shall not retain documents related to the investigation in any of 
18
the complainant's personnel files.  All disciplinary actions taken against employees for 
19
violation of Defendant's ADA anti-discrimination policy will be retained in the violator's 
20
personnel file.  In those cases in which no conclusion could be reached on the allegations, 
21
the investigation documents shall remain in the alleged violator's file. 
22
APOLOGY LETTER 
23
17.  Within fourteen (14) days of the entry of the Decree, Defendant’s CEO 
24
shall prepare a letter of apology to Mr. Calhoon as attached as Attachment B.  Within 5 
25
business days of the date the letter of apology is placed in the mail pursuant to this 
26
Consent Decree, a copy of the letter of apology will be furnished to the Regional 
27
28
-8-

Attorney, Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, Phoenix District Office, 3300 
1
North Central Avenue, Suite 690, Phoenix, Arizona 85012. 
2
REPORTING BY DEFENDANT AND ACCESS BY EEOC 
3
18.  Defendant shall report in writing and in affidavit form to the Regional 
4
Attorney of the Commission's Phoenix District Office at 3300 N. Central Ave., Suite 690, 
5
Phoenix, Arizona 85012, beginning six months from the date of the entry of this Decree, 
6
and thereafter every six months for the duration of the Decree the following information:  
7
a.  Any changes, modifications, revocations, or revisions to its policies 
8
and procedures which concern or affect the subject of disability discrimination and 
9
retaliation.
10
b.  The name, address, position, social security number and telephone 
11
number of any individual who has brought allegations of discrimination and/or 
12
retaliation against Defendant's personnel, formal or informal, including, but not 
13
limited to, management officials, vendors, agents, employees and/or customers, 
14
during the six months preceding the report. The nature of the complaint, 
15
investigatory efforts made by Defendant and the corrective action taken, if any, 
16
shall be specified. 
17
c.  The registry of persons attending the seminar(s) required in 
18
Paragraph 10(e) of this Decree and a list of current personnel employed by 
19
Defendant on the days of the seminar-training sessions.  
20
d.  Confirmation that:  (i) the Notice required in Paragraph 6 of this 
21
Decree was posted and the location(s) where it was posted; and (ii) the policies 
22
required in Paragraph 13 were distributed to each current and new employee and 
23
posted.
24
19.  The Commission, upon reasonable notice, shall have the right to enter and 
25
inspect Defendant’s premises to ensure compliance with this Decree and the ADA's 
26
prohibition of disability discrimination, as well as retaliation.
27
28

This notice is posted pursuant to a consent decree entered into in the Americans

It is unlawful under federal law (the Americans with Disabilities Act) and state law 
to discriminate against an employee on the basis of disability.  It is also unlawful to 
retaliate against any person because the person protested discriminatory practices 
or contacted the EEOC. 
Cowboy’s RV Mart will not discriminate against any employee on the basis of 
disability and will not retaliate against any employee. 
If you believe you have been discriminated against by Cowboy’s RV Mart, you 
have the right to seek assistance from:

85012, (602) 640-5000; or

Office, 1275 W. Washington, Phoenix, Arizona, 85007, (602) 255-5263. 
and/or have the right to file a charge with the EEOC or ACRD if you believe you 
are being discriminated against.

management official of Cowboy’s RV Mart  for (1) opposing discriminatory 
practices made unlawful by federal law, (2) filing a charge or assisting or 
participating in the filing of a charge of discrimination, or (3) assisting or 
participating in an investigation or proceeding brought under state or federal law 
anti-discrimination laws.  Should any such retaliatory actions be taken against you, 
you should immediately contact the EEOC or the ACRD and the address or 
telephone numbers listed above.
